content: The "Rio Grande Natural Area Act" establishes the Rio Grande Natural Area and defines key terms like Commission and Secretary. The Rio Grande Natural Area in Colorado is established to conserve natural, historic, cultural, and wildlife resources along the Rio Grande River. Boundaries extend a quarter mile on each side of the river, and a map and legal description will be prepared by the Secretary. The Secretary will prepare a map and legal description of the Rio Grande Natural Area, which will have the same legal force as if included in the Act and will be available for public inspection. SEC. 4. ESTABLISHMENT OF THE COMMISSION. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission is established to advise the Secretary on the Natural Area and prepare a management plan for non-Federal land. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from the Bureau of Land Management and the Alamosa National Wildlife Refuge manager. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from the Bureau of Land Management and the Alamosa National Wildlife Refuge manager. Members are appointed based on recommendations from the Governor of Colorado and include representatives from the Colorado Division of Wildlife, Colorado Division of Water Resources, Rio Grande Water Conservation District, as well as members representing the general public and citizens of the local region. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from various organizations and the general public. Members serve a 5-year term and may be reappointed. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, serving 5-year terms without compensation. The Commission elects a chairperson and holds quarterly meetings. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission elects a chairperson and holds quarterly public meetings. The Commission can request technical assistance from the Secretary and other Federal agencies. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 5. The Commission may conduct hearings, meetings, and receive evidence as needed to carry out the Act. They can also enter into cooperative agreements with Colorado or other entities for managing non-Federal land in the Natural Area. They must assist the Secretary in implementing the management plan to preserve natural, historic, cultural, scientific, scenic, wildlife, and recreational resources of the Natural Area. The Commission may assist in preserving State land and wildlife, increasing public awareness of natural resources, and encouraging political subdivisions in the State of Colorado. The Commission aims to increase public awareness and appreciation of natural resources in the Natural Area, encourage land use policies consistent with the management plan, and assist private landowners in implementing the plan. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The Secretary and the Commission, along with relevant agencies and landowners, must prepare management plans for the Natural Area within 4 years of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will focus on Federal land, while the Commission will address non-Federal land. The Commission is responsible for preparing a management plan for non-Federal land in the Natural Area, which must be submitted to the Secretary for approval or disapproval. If the plan is disapproved, the Secretary will take necessary action. If the management plan for non-Federal land in the Natural Area is disapproved, the Commission must notify the Commission of the reasons and allow for revisions to be submitted. The Secretary and the Commission must cooperate to ensure consistent management plans for Federal and non-Federal land in the Natural Area. The management plans must consider existing Federal, State, and local plans to create a unified preservation, restoration, and conservation plan. Federal land management plans must comply with the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. The preservation, restoration, and conservation plan for the Natural Area must comply with the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 and be consistent with adjacent land management plans. It will be considered an amendment to the San Luis Resource Management Plan and include an inventory of resources in the area. The preservation plan for the Natural Area, as an amendment to the San Luis Resource Management Plan, includes an inventory of resources and recommendations for resource management to protect the area. The Secretary shall publish notice of the management plans for the Natural Area in the Federal Register, including recommendations for resource management to protect the area and preserve its natural values. SEC. 7. ADMINISTRATION OF NATURAL AREA. The Secretary administers the Federal land in the Natural Area in accordance with laws and the management plan, focusing on conservation, restoration, and protection of natural resources while allowing for education, scientific study, and limited public recreation. The Natural Area is managed by the Secretary to focus on conservation, restoration, and protection of natural resources. This includes allowing for education, scientific study, and limited public recreation, protecting wildlife habitat, prohibiting water storage facilities, and reducing or removing roads and motorized vehicles in the area. The Natural Area is managed to focus on conservation, restoration, and protection of natural resources, including reducing or removing roads and motorized vehicles. The Secretary is encouraged to negotiate with the State of Colorado and water users to determine beneficial streamflow changes. The Secretary is encouraged to negotiate with the State of Colorado, the Rio Grande Water Conservation District, and affected water users to accommodate beneficial streamflow changes in the Natural Area. The management plan for private land in the area applies only if the landowner agrees in writing. Federal land in the area is withdrawn from public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws. The Secretary may acquire land in the Natural Area from willing sellers. The Secretary has the authority to acquire land in the Natural Area from willing sellers through purchase, exchange, or donation. Any acquired land must be managed according to the management plan and the Act. The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act does not apply to the Natural Area. The effect of Section 8 is not specified. The Act does not amend the Rio Grande Compact, authorize regulation of private land in the Natural Area, impose mandatory streamflow requirements, create a Federal reserved water right, impose more restrictive Federal water quality standards, or prevent Colorado from acquiring an instream.
